thread.section_title: Commodities Market News - Yahoo!7 Australia Finance
thread.title: Banks drag share market lower

title: Banks drag share market lower
text:
Banks drag share market lower AAP – 11 minutes ago 
Steep declines by the big four banks have pushed the share market deep into the red. 
Ongoing falls in commodity prices also weighed on the energy players and mining stocks. 
The financial sector's fall, as Commonwealth Bank traded ex-dividend, was the biggest drag, CommSec market analyst Steven Daghlian said. 
"We are at our weakest levels since the 20th of January, and August is one of the worst months we have had since May 2012," he said. 
"The financial sector is holding things back the most, largely because of CBA which was expected to lose ground given its recent capital raising, but it is also trading ex-dividend today." 
CBA dropped $4.36, or 5.36 per cent, to $76.91, ANZ shed 55 cents to $28.97, National Australia Bank fell 50 cents to $31.76 and Westpac was 28 cents weaker at $31.66. 
BHP Billiton lost 22 cents to $24.98, Rio Tinto declined 30 cents to $50.59, while Fortescue Metals gained 14.5 cents to $1.985 as it again rejected speculation of assets sales. 
Woodside Petroleum fell 54 cents to $32.05 and Santos lost 14 cents to $5.84. 
Insurer QBE rose five cents to $14.02 after lifting its half year profit and dividend. 
Australia's largest rail and freight operator Asciano soared after backing a $12 billion takeover offer from Canada's Brookfield Infrastructure Group, its shares gaining 58 cents, or 7.15 per cent, to $8.69. 
Electronics retailer Dick Smith plunged 33 cents, or 16.5 per cent, to $1.67 due to disappointing same store sales growth. 
KEY FACTS 
* At the close on Tuesday, the benchmark S&P/ASX200 index was down 64.6 points, or 1.2 per cent, at 5,303.1 points. 
* The broader All Ordinaries index was down 59.2 points, or 1.1 per cent, at 5,309.4 points. 
* The September share price index futures contract was 52 points lower at 5,250, with 38,270 contracts traded. 
* The price of gold in Sydney at 1700 AEST was $US1,118.10 per fine ounce, down $US1.80 on Monday's price of $US1,119.90. 
* National turnover was 2.08 billion securities worth $7.2 billion. @y7finance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook Nine gets 'above-market' price for HQ AAP 
The Nine Network has sold its historic Willoughby headquarters in Sydney to a Hong Kong property investor for $147.5 …
